Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of warrior to left (leg with added red greave, part of mantle and shield rim remaining); on right, part of draped figure (chiton and red himation remaining) to left; part of incised rosette as filling ornament.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of Louvre F6
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belong to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.556, AN1896-1908-G.557 (3 joining fragmentss), AN1896-1908-G.558, AN1896-1908-G.559, AN1896-1908-G.561 and AN1896-1908-G.130.16. All showing warriors leaving home. The sherd may belong to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.577.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 265, no. B191)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0147) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 94, pl. II, no. 14)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
